main_definition: In various contexts, a vector is an entity that has both magnitude (size) and direction.

meanings_and_examples.example: A three-dimensional arrow pointing in the x, y, z directions represents a mathematical vector.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Physics and engineering term for force or motion direction
meanings_and_examples.example: The velocity of an object is a vector since it has both speed (magnitude) and direction.
A list of coordinates representing the location of points in space, like the pixels on a screen, can be represented as a set of vectors.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Statistical concept for direction and magnitude of differences between observations
meanings_and_examples.example: In principal component analysis, data is transformed into a new coordinate system where the greatest variance by any projection of the data comes to lie on the first axis (vector).

meanings_and_examples.definition: Biology term describing physical properties in an organism's phenotype
meanings_and_examples.example: The orientation of certain cells or tissues can be considered vectors as they have a specific direction and length.
